Typically, diagnostic tests for thoracic back pain are not required. However, if you have persistent pain or concerns about underlying conditions, your healthcare provider may recommend some of the following tests:
X-rays: These can help identify fractures, osteoporosis, or spinal misalignment.
CT scans: Computed tomography scans provide detailed cross-sectional images of the thoracic spine, useful in diagnosing herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or tumor-like conditions.
MRI: Magnetic resonance imaging scans can reveal soft tissue abnormalities like herniated discs and spinal muscle strain, and may also detect tumors, infections, or inflammation.
Blood tests: Certain conditions causing thoracic back pain (e.g., infection, cancer) may be identified through blood tests, including complete blood count (CBC), ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation rate), and CRP (C-reactive protein).
Bone density scan: If osteoporosis is suspected, a bone density scan (DEX

When are disease - modifying antirheumatic drugs usually prescribed? - Diseases of the Rheum - Q & A
Q: When are disease -modifying antirheumatoid drugs usually prescribed?
A: Disease-modifying antir rheumatic drugs (DMARDs) are usually prescribed when symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis are moderate to severe and have not responded to a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) alone. They are typically started early in the course of the disease, while the patient is still experiencing active inflammation and joint damage. The goal is to slow down the progression of the disease and prevent long-term joint damage. DMARDs are also often combined with corticosteroids to provide rapid relief of symptoms and prevent joint destruction. The decision to prescribe DMARDs and the choice of specific medications are made based on the severity of the disease, patient factors, and potential side effects of the medications. In some cases, DMARDs may be initiated earlier in the disease course if there is evidence of joint damage or widespread inflammation

Active tuberculosis: DMARDs can mask the signs and symptoms of tuberculosis, making it difficult to diagnose and treat this infection. Classically , someone who develops an intracranial extradural haematoma loses consciousness at the time of the head injury and then has a ' lucid interval ' of a few hours after the head injury where they appear relatively well and normal . If you do not lose consciousness after the initial head injury , or if you regain consciousness , you may experience drowsiness or a severe headache . Sometimes a fit ( seizure ) can occur . Some people with an intracranial extradural haematoma can be talking one minute and appear relatively well and can then become very ill and lose consciousness the next . natural_text: Aspirin was used in the past for preventing strokes if you have AF but is not as effective as warfarin and is just as likely to cause problems . Aspirin is therefore no longer recommended . The standard anticoagulant has , for many years , been warfarin . There are also new medicines that are as effective as warfarin and may have some advantages . These medicines are dabigatran , apixaban , rivaroxaban and edoxaban . Warfarin can interact with some foods , alcohol and other medicines . Some of the newer anticoagulants ( dabigatran , apixaban , rivaroxaban and edoxaban ) have less interaction with foods , alcohol and other medicines . If you take warfarin you will need regular blood tests ( INR tests ) to check how quickly your blood clots . Blood tests may be needed quite often at first but should become less often quite quickly . The aim is to get the dose of warfarin just right so your blood does not clot as easily as normal but not so much as to cause bleeding problems . Dabigatran , apixaban , edoxaban and rivaroxaban do not need regular blood tests .,

What are the benefits and risks of anticoagulant medicines? Anticoagulants help prevent blood clots from forming in your blood vessels, which can reduce the risk of heart attack, stroke and other conditions like deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism. However, they also increase the risk of bleeding, either internally or externally. Some people may experience side effects such as gastrointestinal upset, bruising or bleeding from minor cuts. In rare cases, allergic reactions can occur. It's important to weigh the benefits and communicate any concerns with your doctor.

natural_text: The benefit of taking warfarin or one of the newer medicines is to reduce your risk of stroke . The main side - effect of these medicines is an increased risk of serious bleeding . Taking warfarin has a risk of bleeding and the dose of warfarin needs to be checked regularly . Therefore you will need to have regular blood tests if you are taking warfarin . If severe bleeding does happen , an injection of vitamin K will help to stop the effect of warfarin and so help to stop the bleeding . The newer medicines ( dabigatran , apixaban , rivaroxaban and edoxaban ) also increase the risk of bleeding . However , they do not increase the risk of bleeding into the brain ( intracranial haemorrhage ) by nearly as much as warfarin . You will not need to have regular blood tests or change the dose of medicine you are taking with the newer medicines . Apixaban , rivaroxaban and edoxaban currently have no treatment to stop the effect of these medicines if you do have severe bleeding . Dabigatran can be reversed quickly with idarucizumab ( Praxbind ® ) . The newer agents do not stay in your body for as long as warfarin does . This means that any problem with bleeding disappears more quickly - usually in 12 - 24 hours .,

Glycogen storage diseases (GSD) are a group of inherited metabolic disorders characterized by abnormalities in glycogen metabolism. These disorders result from mutations in enzymes involved in the synthesis, breakdown, or storage of glycogen. The diagnosis of GSD is based on the presentation of clinical symptoms, biochemical tests, and genetic testing. Some common tests used to diagnose GSD include liver biopsy, blood tests for enzyme activities, and genetic studies. Treatment options for GSD vary depending on the specific type of disease, symptoms, and age of the patient. Enzyme replacement therapy may be used in some types of G
natural_text: The treatment for glycogen storage disorders varies depending on which disorder you have . With most , the treatment aims are to stabilise your blood sugar and energy levels within your body . This is normally achieved by using corn flour ( as used in thickening gravy ) or nutritional supplements such as glucose . A high - protein diet may also be helpful in some glycogen storage disorders . Some people with glycogen storage disorders who do not respond to nutritional supplements may occasionally need a liver transplant . People with glycogen storage disorders affecting their immune system may need to take regular antibiotic medication to protect against infection . In some glycogen storage disorders , clinical trials have successfully used treatment involving replacement of the enzymes that are deficient or not working normally . For example , in glycogen storage disorder type II , this treatment has been shown to help reverse the heart problems and muscle weakness that can occur . Other clinical trials are underway that are looking at gene therapy as a treatment . This is where doctors and scientists aim to cure genetic diseases by introducing normal genes into patients to overcome the effects of faulty genes , using techniques of genetic engineering .,

prompt: What is the outlook for Mallory - Weiss syndrome ?
watermarked_text: What is the outlook for Mallory - Weiss syndrome? Last reviewed May 2019. Mallory-Weiss syndrome is a condition characterized by a tear in the mucus membrane of the lining of the esophagus. If the tear is small and superficial, it usually heals on its own with minimal complications. However, if the tear is large or extends deeper into the muscle tissue, it may develop into more serious complications, such as bleeding, stomach ulcers, or infections. Immediate medical attention is necessary to manage any significant bleeding and prevent future complications. Treatment typically includes medications to control bleeding, pain management, fluid replacement, and in some cases, endoscopy to repair the tear or remove any damaged tissue. Most people recover from Mallory- Weiss syndrome without long-term consequences. However, recurrent episodes or bleeding complications may occur, especially in individuals with pre-existing conditions such as liver disease, anticoagulation therapy, or severe vomiting. Close monitoring and follow-up with a healthcare provider are essential to ensure proper healing and prevent future issues.

natural_text: With treatment , most people make a full recovery . If left untreated , about half of people with active TB eventually die of the infection . prompt: Who should have ' screening tests ' for tuberculosis ?
watermarked_text:
Who should have'screening tests'for tuberculosis? Screening tests for tuberculosis should be done in people who are more prone to develop the disease due to various reasons. The following persons are at high risk and should have'screening tests' for tuberculosis :
People with HIV infection/AIDS. TB can be in the latent stage for many years and may reactivate in patients with weakened immune systems. HIV-infected individuals are at increased risk for active TB and should be screened regularly.
People with a history of treatment for TB. Patients who have been previously treated for TB are at risk for relapse or development of drug-resistant TB and should have regular follow-up testing.
People with close contact with individuals diagnosed with TB. People who live or work in close proximity to someone with active TB are at increased exposure risk and should be tested for infection.
People with immunosuppression. Individuals with conditions that suppress the immune system, such as those on long-term corticosteroid therapy or other immunosuppressive drugs, are at higher risk for active tuberculosis.

Outlook for greater trochanteric pain syndrome
Greater trochanter pain syndrome is usually a self-limiting condition and typically improves with time. This condition usually resolves within 3-6 months with conservative management. If symptoms persist beyond 6 months without an identifiable cause, further investigation is recommended to rule out other underlying conditions that may be contributing to the pain. In some cases, surgical intervention may be considered if the condition does not improve with non-surgical management. It is important to follow the advised treatment plan and to report any worsening or new symptoms to your healthcare provider. This will help ensure the best possible outcome for your condition. Early diagnosis and intervention can make a significant difference to quality of life for individuals with ASDs and their families.
What causes autistic spectrum disorders? The exact cause of ASDs is not yet fully understood. However, research suggests that a combination of genetic and environmental factors may play a role. Genetic factors can include inherited genes or spontaneous mutations, while environmental factors can include exposure to certain substances or infections during critical periods of brain development. It's important to remember that having a genetic predisposition to ASDs does not mean that a person will definitely develop the condition.

The diagnosis of autism spectrum disorders (ASDs) is based on the presence of characteristic symptoms, such as impaired social interaction and communication, and restricted and repetitive patterns of behavior. These symptoms must be present in early childhood and cause significant impairment in functioning. The diagnosis is typically made by a team of professionals, including a psychologist or psychiatrist, who conduct a comprehensive evaluation that includes a thorough clinical interview, standardized developmental screening tests, and possibly observations in different settings. The key diagnostic tool is the Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule (ADOS), which evaluates social and communication skills and behavior, and the Autism Diagnostic Interview-Revised (ADI-R), which assesses the presence and severity of autism symptoms in two different settings: the ADOS at home and the ADI-R in a clinical setting. How is the diagnosis made for Behçet's Disease? +
The diagnosis of Behçet's Disease is made based on a combination of clinical symptoms and signs, laboratory findings, and the presence of certain characteristic features. The criteria used to diagnose Behçet’s Disease include:
Recurrent oral ulcers: The presence of recurrent painful mouth sores that typically heal without scarring within 2-3 weeks.
Genital ulcers: Development of ulcers in the genital area, such as the vulva, vagina, or penis, at least three times during one year.
Eyes inflammation: The occurrence of eyewithdrawal lesions, including anterior uveitis or posterior uveitis, at least twice within one year.
Joint pain: Recurrent joint pain and swelling, affecting at least two joints, at least once during one year
Skin lesions: The appearance of erythema nodosum (subcutaneous lumps) or papulopustular lesions (bumps and pus-filled bumps) during the course of the disease.

natural_text: A TIA causes symptoms similar to a stroke but the symptoms last for less than 24 hours . It is due to a temporary lack of blood to a part of the brain . In most cases , a TIA is caused by a tiny blood clot that becomes stuck in a small blood vessel ( artery ) in the brain . This blocks the blood flow and a part of the brain is starved of oxygen . The affected part of the brain is without oxygen for just a few minutes and soon recovers . This is because the blood clot either breaks up quickly or nearby blood vessels are able to compensate . Unlike a stroke , the symptoms of a TIA soon go . However , you should see a doctor urgently if you have a TIA , as you are at increased risk of having a full stroke . natural_text: LARCs are ideal for women who do not want a baby in the near future . This might be because you think you have completed your family and do not think you want more children , but want to keep your options open . Or it might be because you are young and not wishing to have children for some years to come . Or because you do n't want children at all . Or because you are not currently in a position to have children , because of your job , relationship or finances . The great thing about LARCs is the word " reversible " - so if your situation changes , you can stop using them and become fertile again . You do n't need to take a tablet every day , so for most LARCs , you can forget about contraception for years at a time . This makes them more reliable ( as they do n't need you to remember , other than when they are due to be replaced ) . The main downside is that they all require a small procedure of some sort . However , this does not have to be done very often , and provides long - term , reliable contraception once you have done it .,

What are the treatments for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease? The treatments for COPD include:
  1. Lifestyle Changes: Smoking cessation, avoiding exposure to lung irritants, maintaining a healthy weight, and regular exercise.
  2. Medications: Bronchodilators are prescribed to relieve the symptoms of COPD. Inhaled corticosteroids may also be used for reducing airway inflammation.
  3. Oxygen Therapy: Supplemental oxygen may be necessary for people with low oxygen levels in their blood.
  4. Pulmonary Rehabilitation: A comprehensive program that includes exercise, education, and support for improving lung function and overall quality of life.
  5. Surgery: Surgical options such as bullectomy (removal of infected or damaged lung tissue), lung volume reduction surgery, or even lung transplantation may be considered for severe cases of COPD.

Q: What are + blockers and how do they work?
+ blockers are a type of medication that helps to relax blood vessels, allowing blood to flow more easily and lowering blood pressure. They work by blocking the action of certain chemicals that cause blood vessels to narrow.
Q: How effective are + blockers?
+ blockers can be very effective in reducing blood pressure and relieving symptoms of heart failure. They help to improve blood flow, reduce the workload on the heart, and decrease the risk of cardiovascular events.
Q: What conditions are + blockers used to treat?
+ blockers may be prescribed for a variety of conditions, including hypertension (high blood pressure), angina (chest pain caused by reduced blood flow to the heart), heart failure, and Raynaud's phenomenon.

natural_text: There are various causes of LUTS . The more common causes include : An enlarged prostate gland . The prostate gland ( referred to from now on here as the prostate ) is situated around the neck of your bladder . When this gets bigger it can cause voiding symptoms . See the separate leaflet called Prostate Gland Enlargement for more details . Overactive bladder . As men ( and women ) get older , it is more common to develop bladder control problems . Your bladder may also be less able to store urine . This leads to you needing to pass urine more frequently and can even lead to leakage of urine at times ( incontinence ) . See the separate leaflet called Overactive Bladder Syndrome for more details . Water balance problems . As people get older , it becomes harder for the body to reduce the amount of urine that they pass at night . This leads to the need to pass urine more often at night . Therefore , at the age of 65 and over it can be normal to pass urine at least once a night . Other causes of LUTS include diabetes mellitus , urinary infections , bladder stones , prostate cancer , bladder cancer and neurological conditions ( eg , multiple sclerosis ) .,

natural_text: Many people with globus sensation are worried that it could be a sign of another problem , particularly a cancer . Globus sensation needs to be distinguished from a difficulty with swallowing ( dysphagia ) . When we eat , food passes from our mouth , down the gullet ( oesophagus ) , into the stomach and then into the small and then large intestine . For people with dysphagia , there is a delay in the passage of fluids or solids from the mouth , down the gullet and to the stomach . Someone with dysphagia will notice that their foods , particularly solid foods , feel like they are getting stuck as they swallow . There are a number of problems that can lead to the symptom of dysphagia . The problem can stem from something going wrong at any point in the swallowing process , from the mouth to lower down in the gullet . See the separate leaflet called Difficulty Swallowing ( Dysphagia ) for the many conditions which can be possible causes . Sometimes it can be very difficult to tell the difference between globus sensation and dysphagia . As mentioned above , one clue could be that unlike someone with dysphagia , someone with globus sensation does not usually have any problems eating or drinking . Also , dysphagia can be constant and may become gradually worse over time , whereas globus sensation symptoms tend to come and go .,

Complications of a fungal scalp infection, in most cases, are relatively mild. However, it is possible for the infection to spread to other parts of the body, causing further discomfort. The infection can, for example, spread to the face, causing perioral candidiasis, or to the nails, causing onychomycosis. Alopecia areata is also a complication that can occur, where hair loss develops on the scalp suddenly and possibly permanently.

  1. Potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation: A sample of skin is taken from the affected area, treated with KOH, and examined under a microscope to look for fungal elements.
  2. Fungal culture: A sample is taken from an active lesion and cultured in a petri dish to grow the fungus.

Are there different types of antithyroid medication for hyperthyroidism?   Yes, there are several types of antihyroid medications used to treat hyperthyroid symptoms. These include:
  1. Propylthiouracil (PTU): PTU is an oral medication that helps to reduce the thyroid hormones produced by the thyroid gland.
  2. Methimazole (Tapazole): Methimazole is an oral medication that also decreases thyroid hormone production by interfering with the production of thyroid hormones in the thyroid gland. It is often the preferred choice over PTU.
  3. Carbimazole: Carbimazole is another oral medication that hinders thyroid hormone production, similar to methimazole.
  4. Radioactive iodine (RAI): RAI is not an antithyrotic medication, but rather a form of radioactive iodine that is taken orally to destroy the overactive thyroid tissue. It may be used when a patient is not suitable for antithyriotic medications or surgery.

Chronic open-angle glaucoma (COAG) is a type of glaucoma. Glaucoma is a group of eye conditions that can lead to optic nerve damage, which in turn can result in vision loss and even blindness. The key difference between glaucoma generally and COAG specifically is the angle formed between the cornea and the iris at the front of the eye. In glaucoma, this angle becomes blocked, causing fluid to build up and putting pressure on the optic nerve. COAG is often referred to as the sneak thief of sight because it usually progresses slowly and without symptoms, making early detection crucial. HPV is a common sexually transmitted infection that can be transmitted through direct skin-to-skin contact with an infected person. HPV is responsible for causing anogenital wart outbreaks. The same HPV types that cause anogenital lesions can also cause various types of cancer, including cervical, anal, penile, vaginal, vulvar, and oropharyngeal (back of the throat) cancers. HPV types 16 and 18 are most commonly linked to the development of anogenital and oroph aryngeal cancers. HPV vaccination is recommended to reduce the risk of infection with these high-risk HPV types and subsequent development of cervical and other anogenital site cancers. Does pain in Ears during Flying happen to everyone?" Answered by: Dr. Anthony Insana, ENT Specialist, answered on Tuesday, May 12, 2009
Pain in the ear during flights is a common problem. It is often referred to as aero-otitis media. It occurs due to changes in air pressure during ascent and descent in an aircraft. This pressure can cause the Eustachian tube, which connects the middle ear to the back of the throat, to become blocked. When the tube is blocked, fluid from the middle ear cannot escape and the pressure inside the ear builds up, leading to pain, discomfort, and sometimes a feeling of fullness in the ear. The pain may be mild to severe and can affect one or both ears. It is more common in people who have a cold or allergies, have a young child, or are on certain medications that cause nasal congestion. However, it can affect anyone, regardless of age or medical history. To alleviate the symptoms, there are various measures that

Groin injuries: Groin injuries such as muscle strains and groin pulls can cause pain in the area. These injuries occur when the muscles and tendons in the groin become overused or torn.

natural_text: When an ear is noted to be prominent within the first few weeks of life , it is possible to reshape it by applying a small splint to the rim . The cartilage or gristle of a new - born 's ear is very floppy and easily remoulded and after several weeks of splintage a permanent correction can be achieved . The older the child , the more stiff the cartilage and the longer the period of splintage must be . By the age of six months the cartilage is too hard to be remoulded and a surgical solution is required . Pinnaplasty or otoplasty is an operation which adjusts the shape of the cartilage within the ear to create the missing folds and to allow the ear to lie closer to the side of the head . Because the operation is carried out from behind the ears , a small scar is left close to the groove between the ear and the side of the head . The procedure can be carried out under local anaesthetic , but in young children a general anaesthetic is usually required . Where the lobe of the ear is especially large , a small procedure to reduce its size may also be required .,

Severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, is a viral respiratory illness caused by the coronavirus SARS-Co V. It was first identified in China in 2002 and had spread to more than two dozen countries. SARS is not caused by tuberculosis, influenza, or meningitis. It is characterized by symptoms such as high fever, cough, and shortness of breath. In severe cases, it can lead to pneumonia, kidney failure, and even death. The virus is transmitted through respiratory droplets and close personal contact, making it highly contagious in crowded areas and among household members. To control the spread of SARS, strict measures such as isolation and quarantine were implemented, along with proper hygiene practices like wearing masks and hand sanitizing. The global outbreak of SARS prompted significant international efforts to understand, contain, and combat the disease. Answer: D) Sars-CoV

Adults : 1. Diverticulitis : Inflammation or infection of the diverticula (small pouches) that can occur in the wall of the colon, often causing LLQ pain. 2. Kidney stones : Stones can form in the kidneys and cause severe LLQ pain, along with symptoms like nausea and vomiting. 3. Ruptured appendicitis : This is a common cause of LLQ

natural_text: How much the aorta is narrowed in coarctation of the aorta can be different in different people . Some babies will be born with severe narrowing which can lead to symptoms soon after they are born ( see below ) . However , in others , the narrowing is less severe and symptoms may not be noticed until later . In some people , the narrowing may gradually get worse over time and therefore lead to symptoms . Occasionally , coarctation of the aorta does not cause any symptoms or is not detected until adult life . Symptoms result from heart failure because the heart is not able to push blood through the narrowed part of the aorta . This causes a back - pressure of blood and congestion of the lungs , leading to symptoms including shortness of breath . Patients with less severe narrowing will present later as they develop extra blood vessels , called collateral blood vessels , so that some blood is able to bypass the narrowed part of the aorta . These collateral blood vessels may be enough for some time but , eventually , the heart is no longer able to cope and symptoms of heart failure start to appear .,

Motor neurone disease, also known as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that primarily affects motor neurons. These neurons are responsible for controlling voluntary muscles, including those used for walking, breathing, and speaking.
While motor neurone function is severely impacted in ALS, other areas of the nervous system, such as the senses of touch, pain, and temperature, are relatively unaffected. Additionally, the cerebellum, which plays a role in coordination and balance, is also spared in this condition. Therefore, individuals with ALS may retain their reflexes and the ability to perceive sensations like touch or pain, while experiencing difficulties with muscle movement and function. Endobronchinal ultrasound -guided transbronchical needle aspiration (EBUS-TBNA) is a minimally invasive procedure that utilizes ultrasound imaging through the flexible bronchoscope to guide the passage of a 22-gauge needle into the mediastinal or peridiaphragmatic lesion.
The principle steps involved are :
1. Flexible bronchoscopy is performed to the level of the carina.
2. Endobronchbial ultrasound (EBUS) is used to locate and characterize the target lesion.
3. A 22-gage needle is advanced through the working channel of the bronchoscope, under real-time ultrasound guidance, into the lesion.
4. Aspiration is performed, with the stylet removed, to obtain a sample of the lesion for cytological analysis.

natural_text: Endobronchial ultrasound - guided transbronchial needle aspiration is a special technique used to take samples of body tissue from inside the chest . It is also known as EBUS TBNA for short . The procedure is carried out using a special kind of bronchoscope . This is a thin flexible kind of ' telescope ' which passes through the mouth and into the airways . The bronchoscope ( often shortened to ' scope ' ) allows doctors to see inside the lungs and carry out the procedure . Endobronchial means from inside or within the bronchus . The bronchi ( the plural of bronchus ) are large tube - like airways . They take air from the windpipe ( trachea ) to the smaller airways , called the bronchioles . During the procedure ultrasound is used to help the doctor doing the test see the structures just outside the airways . This gives the test the first part of its name . The scope also contains a very fine needle . This needle is used to take samples of body tissue by pushing through the bronchus to the tissue on the other side . The needle holds the sample of tissue ; this is called aspiration . Transbronchial means across the bronchus , giving the name transbronchial needle aspiration .,

prompt: What is the cause of a transient ischaemic attack ?
watermarked_text:
What is the cause of a transient ischaemic attack? What is the cause?
A transient ischaemie attack (TIA) is a type of stroke, but it is reversible. It usually occurs when blood flow to the brain is temporarily impaired, often due to a blood clot. The clot can be caused by atherosclerosis, which is the buildup of fatty deposits on the inner walls of arteries. Other causes include platelet disorders, blood vessel inflammation, irregular heart rhythm, and high blood pressure. The symptoms of a TIA are similar to those of a stroke, including sudden weakness or numbness in the face, arm, or leg, difficulties with speech or language, and a change in vision. However, the symptoms typically last for only a short period of time and most people recover within a short period. TIAs can be warnings of a more serious stroke and should be taken seriously. A healthcare provider can evaluate the event and recommend steps to reduce the risk of future strokes. Source: Merck Manual Professional Edition
What are the common causes
natural_text: In most cases , a TIA is caused by a tiny blood clot that becomes stuck in a small blood vessel ( artery ) in the brain . This blocks the blood flow , and a part of the brain is starved of oxygen . The affected part of the brain is without oxygen for just a few minutes , and soon recovers . This is because the blood clot either breaks up quickly , or nearby blood vessels are able to compensate . There are other uncommon causes of a TIA . These include : Blood clotting problems . Tiny bleeds into the brain . Blood disorders such as polycythaemia and sickle cell anaemia where the blood is very thick . Spasm of a small artery in the brain . Other uncommon problems of the brain or its blood vessels . However , these are not dealt with further in this leaflet .,

Ketones may appear in the blood and urine due to starvation or because of a lack of insulin . The presence of ketones in the urine may be a warning of diabetic ketoacidosis . Glomerulonechritis is a serious inflammation of the glomeruli that can be caused by factors such as drugs, infection, autoimmune reactions, and hemolytic diseases. Its prognosis depends on several factors including:
The severity of the disease: Patients with more severe symptoms and underlying conditions are at a higher risk of developing chronic kidney disease or experiencing additional complications.
The presence of underlying conditions: Certain underlying conditions, such as diabetes or hypertension, can increase the risk of developing complications or worsening of the disease.
Response to treatment: The response to appropriate treatment, including medications, blood pressure control, and dialysis (if necessary), is an important factor in determining the overall prognosis.
In general, the prognosis of Glomerularonephritis can vary depending on the specific cause and individual patient factors.
